user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_time_t *abs_wakeup_time)
{
    struct timespec                    limit;
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    limit.tv_sec  = OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds(*abs_wakeup_time);
    limit.tv_nsec = OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart(*abs_wakeup_time);

    pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex, &impl->mut);
    status = pthread_cond_timedwait(&impl->cv, &impl->mut, &limit);
    pthread_cleanup_pop(false);

    if (status == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        return OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT;
    }
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl:
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    int64 ticks; /**< Ticks elapsed since reference point */
} OS_time_t
...
static inline int64 OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds(OS_time_t tm)
{
    return (tm.ticks / OS_TIME_TICKS_PER_SECOND);
}
...
static inline uint32 OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart(OS_time_t tm)
{
    return (uint32)OS_TimeGetFractionalPart(tm) * OS_TIME_TICK_RESOLUTION_NS;
}
...
static void OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex(void *mut)
{
    pthread_mutex_unlock(mut);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No usage of any <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) appears in OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl or in the provided related symbols. The code only performs: retrieving an entry from OS_impl_condvar_table via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, integer conversions to fill struct timespec fields, and pthread calls (pthread_cond_timedwait, pthread_cleanup_push/pop, pthread_mutex_unlock). None of these involve the Standard Library string handling functions covered by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17, so there are no code fragments here that need investigation for out-of-bounds accesses caused by <string.h> functions.
